Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Impact of Alternative Regimes of Property and Ownership on Economic Growth

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Privatization has been widely promoted as a vehicle for increasing market participation and stimulating economic growth. There are, however, multiple legal and cultural models within which private property and ownership are constituted, and industries that inadequately manage those terrains have been proven to be particularly vulnerable. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, empirically grounded scientific fieldwork, explores what factors contribute to the success and durability of new economic ventures in contexts where legal and cultural regimes of property vary. The findings of this project will be disseminated to organizations and stakeholders involved in informing public policy aimed at enhancing the participation of underrepresented stakeholders in the economy, and developing improved inclusion in decision-making models, thus improving economic security. The research also fosters international scientific cooperation.

Ognjen Kojanic, under the supervision of Dr. Robert M. Hayden of the University of Pittsburgh, will investigate whether ownership and private property constitute different analytical concepts within certain labor and industrial contexts, and what are the political economic, and cultural implications of that distinction. Looking at a worker-owned factory in Croatia, a site marked by emergent markets following entry into the European Union, this research has three objectives: (1) to track the transformation of concepts of property, (2) to explore the economic relations that emerge from worker-ownership to determine the corporate form being developed, and (3) to examine how workers articulate a political and economic ideology of ownership separate from those of property. Over the course of 12 months, Kojanic will conduct semi-structured interviews, participant observation, and archival research. This case study will contribute to the debate on property relations in social sciences by testing the analytic value of the underused concept of ownership, as differentiated from the concept of property.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Privatization has been widely promoted as a vehicle for increasing market participation and stimulating economic growth. There are, however, multiple legal and cultural models within which private property and ownership are constituted, and industries that inadequately manage those terrains have been proven to be particularly vulnerable.

This project examined what factors contribute to the success and durability of economic ventures in contexts where legal and cultural regimes of property vary. It aimed to contribute to an ethnographically grounded understanding of the aftermath of the privatization of ITAS (acronym for Ivanec Machine Tool Company in Croatian), which is a metalworking company based in Ivanec, Croatia. It developed a concept of ownership that is different from the concept of property rights: as ownership is a claim based on possession and use of resources that takes the form of a bundle of inseparable rights that is different from the bundle commonly understood as property rights. A three-pronged approach to test the value of this concept was undertaken. First, I tracked changes in the legal frameworks for property in socialist Yugoslavia, and then post-socialist Croatia, as well as the property transformations that ITAS had undergone. Second, I investigated the economic relations that have developed in this case. Finally, I examined how owners of the company articulate a political and economic ideology of ownership, and the connections they maintain with other enterprises and organizations. Thus, the three objectives of the research are the following: 1) Explicate the post-socialist transformation of ownership in Croatia with a specific focus on ITAS; 2) Determine the model of ownership in ITAS; 3) Examine political alliances formed around form of ownership developed in ITAS.

This project has supported the training of a doctoral student in cultural anthropology by providing opportunities for mastering skills relevant for ethnographic research, such as interviewing, participant observation, and photography. The research has also fostered international scientific cooperation. The findings of this project will be disseminated to organizations involved in informing public policy aimed at enhancing the participation of underrepresented stakeholders in the economy, and developing improved inclusion in decision­-making models, thus improving economic security.
